newsitem.title: USA: FPC launches technical review of Fla. nuke.
newsitem.headline: FPC launches technical review of Fla. nuke.

text.p: Florida Power Corp said on Tuesday it has extended an outage at its Crystal River 3 nuclear power plant to review the 19-year old plant's design and equipment operations.
The 860 megawatt plant, in Red Level, Fla., was shut Sept 2 to repair a lubricating oil pipeline to the unit's main turbine generator.
"While the unit was off line for unrelated maintenance, FPC found several design basis issues that require further study," the company said in a statement.
The company said it also planned to "analyze equipment operating margins" during the extended outage.
"The key issues involve the potential capacity of an emergency diesel generator and piping concerns in the emergency feedwater system," the company said.
Citing the extent of the evaluation and anticipated regulatory consultations, the company said it did not expect to restart the plant before the end of the year.
This supported the Daily Status Report issued on Monday by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission which said the plant likely would not return to service until January, 1997.

FPC said it anticipates no problems serving customer load requirements over the autumn since it typically is a season of low electricity demand. Any need for extra power can be met through purchases from outside power suppliers, it added.
FPC is the main subsidiary of St. Petersburg-based Florida Progress Corp and serves 1.3 million customers in central and northern Florida.
